poem_title: THE FABLE of PHAETON Paraphrased From OVID's METAMORPHOSIS.
author: Elizabeth Rowe (n√©e Singer)

lines.line_text: WIth swelling thoughts fixt on his great intent,
Now  had climb'd the Suns ascent;
And to his radiant Father's Pallace came;
Whose heavenly seat lookt blazon'd all with flame:
On Stately Pedestalls erected high
Above the Convex of the utmost Sky:
Its Glorious Front, dazled, yet pleas'd the sight,
With vigorous sallys of AEthereal Light.
The entrance, all divinely deckt, was wrought,
Beyond the invention of a humane thought;
With various figures exquisite and bold,
As the Amazing Novelties they told.
Here awful  rises from the deep,
Around the peaceful  seem to
Here dreadful  the Blust'ring  stride,
And raise a  as they
In mighty  the lovely  swim,
And blewish  the lofty  climb.

stanzas.stanza_text:
WIth swelling thoughts fixt on his great intent,
Now  had climb'd the Suns ascent;
And to his radiant Father's Pallace came;
Whose heavenly seat lookt blazon'd all with flame:
On Stately Pedestalls erected high
Above the Convex of the utmost Sky:
Its Glorious Front, dazled, yet pleas'd the sight,
With vigorous sallys of AEthereal Light.
The entrance, all divinely deckt, was wrought,
Beyond the invention of a humane thought;
With various figures exquisite and bold,
As the Amazing Novelties they told.
Here awful  rises from the deep,
Around the peaceful  seem to
Here dreadful  the Blust'ring  stride,
And raise a  as they
In mighty  the lovely  swim,
And blewish  the lofty  climb.

lines.line_text: Wide from the Shore a pleasant  of Land,
With careless  did it self expand:
Here Mountains, Valleys, Springs, and  Groves,
Flocks, Herds, Unpolish'd Shepherds, and their
The Dryads, Satyrs, Silver Gods, and Fawns,
Had here their Rural Pallaces and Lawns.

lines.line_text: Above all this, appear'd the blest abodes,
And gay-Pavilions of th' Immortal Gods:
Upon a Painted-Zodiack brightly shone
With Glittering Emralds
Here sate in Purple the
(Whom  now trembles to survey:)
Smooth were his Cheeks, most lovely eyes, his brows
Adorn'd with  and his own sacred
Around, the  the  and  attend,
While, at his  the crooked  bend:
The beauteous Spring (more  than all the rest,)
Stood smiling by, clad in a Flowry Vest:
Summer, with  of  her  bound,
And Autumn with  crown'd:
In order next old hoary-Winter stood;

lines.line_text: Surrounded thus with Majesty and State,
Bold  Illustrious  sate:
The God his ventrous Off-spring now espyes;
Amaz'd! demands, What urg'd his enterprize?
And what great Embassy cou'd bring him to the Skies?
of  the doubtful Youth returns,

And doubt no longer my

lines.line_text: what dost thou ask?
Not  himself durst undertake the
Though not a God in the  more great,
Yet even he'd decline our
Can'st thou, a  then supply my
Curb my fierce Steeds, and pass the
So hard and difficult, the  of day
Scarce with  Horses vanquish I the way:
With  on the distant Earth at
We from the  dismal heighth look down
The steep  from thence we swiftly roul:
Nor here our headlong  Brook controul.
Even Lovely  sees my  with dread,
Though every Night she expects me to her
Besides, thou'lt meet a Thousand rugged Jarrs
From the incountring Motions of the
Scarce our Immortal  stem their force:
Betwixt the Bulls sharp hornes then lies thy course,
By  and the  Claws,
The Gastly  and  dreadful Jaws.
Expect no  nor Flowry  there,
Nor Gods, nor Nymphs; but Monsters every where,
Then let a Father's timely Care perswade,
And yet retract the dangerous  thou'st made
Be wise, and urge no more this fatal
Alas, my  too sadly, speaks thee
Of all the Earths, or Seas rich Bosoms hide,
Or  which in upper Air abide;
Ask what thou wilt, or dar'st (besides) to wish;
Do,  ask any thing but
And, by my former Sacred  'tis thine.

lines.line_text: But the  Youth, fixt on his rash design,
With such an Enterprize, the more
His anxious  now boldly claim'd,
Who forc'd to yield. The nimble  soon brought
His  forth in hot  wrought,
By crafty  and the  Art,
Who'd shown immortal skill in every part:
The  and  the purest Gold,
Bright as those  in which they roul'd:
The  all Emboss'd with
And twinkling  of  Lights.

lines.line_text: But now  from her Eastern Bed,
Had, o'er the Expanse her Dewy Mantle spread,
The Sickly Moon the Hemisphere resigns;
And, with her Waning,  declines.
The  grew more  and  still,
And  officious now against his will:
With  his fierce  allays,
Then crowns the Joyful  with his
With tender Speeches caution'd thus the while,
Let not Presumption thy fond Thoughts beguile ,
To give my hot unruly Steeds their course,
But use the  with utmost care and force,
Along a beaten, broad, and oblique way,
Far from the  now lies the
Avoid the  and the hissing
Both  betwixt them keep the Track;
Observe a careful distance from the
Lest thou affront the awful
Nor near the Earth approach,
To  with  I leave the rest.
For, loe the pale  of the
Resigns her  to th' expected
Take up the  or yet, or yet be
And graspa more  enterprize:

lines.line_text: But  as  as
Undaunted, leaps into the
Pleas'd with his glorious charge, nor doubts his Skill
To manage it, he Mounts th'
Aloud th' Immortal Steeds begin to Neigh,
And strike their Fiery  and make
As through she clouds they cut their
And finding now the Reeling  fraught
With nothing congruous to
Unruly grow, and heedless of the
Its feeble  and trembling  disdain;
And, all disorder'd,  of their
Through  unknown to  himself, they
Now near the Fair  who, in vain,
Implor'd more Temperate Quarters in the Main
With Heat reviv'd, see the fierce  roul,
Tho' fix'd his Station near the Frozen Pole.
and drives his
A nimble  untry'd before by them,
As much distress'd, unhappy
From Great  arched Top looks down:
Black  now, and aggravating
Through all his Conscious thoughts triumphant were:
He Curst his  conspicuous Seat, and Birth,
And covets the obscurest place on
To be the Son of  safe below,
Unknown to Gods and Men, would please him now;
So, all confus'd, the hopeless  Raves,
And yields, at last, to the relentless
What can he do? much of the
Is yet Unconquer'd; more he dreads the
That dangerous  nor one clear  can fin'd
In Heaven; nor call his Horses  to mind:
Who now near where the dreadful Scorpion lay,
Hurryd the shatter'd Chariot of the Day:
Proud of the  which from his trembling hands
Now faintly  no  withstands
Their furious  but through the  Sky
They  and  and all disorder'd fly.
Now upward, to the Stars, a  they rend,
Then down agen the frightful  descend:
Below, her  from afar,
With wonder, views her radiant
The exhaled Earth down to its Centre dry,
Wants  her fainting  to supply:
Assaulted with the too prevailing rays,
In fatal Flames, whole  and Mountains blaze:
High  and the Pin'y top
Of pleasant  into Cinders drop:
Old  the  Mount, and high
smoak up to the darkned Sky:
roars, more fierce its entrails glow;
Nor work the  at their Anvils now.
Steep  flame
Nor  Snows the fiercer Fire can tame.

lines.line_text: frys,  chaps, and burns
Her kindling Grove; fair  mourns.
The Airy  and Gloomy Appenine,
With  in the  shine:
Surrounded thus with Smoak, and Wrathful Fires,
Unhappy  almost
within, and  all without,
By's surious Steeds, at pleasure, hurl'd about;
Gasping, and saint, still hurried round, nor more,
Tho prop't by Fate, a  could have bore:
They say, the  now with heat
Adust, and scorch't, diffus'd a Sable Sweat;
And all the wasted  sadly ring
Of some fair  Mourning for her
Nor from the Mightyer Streams the Flame recoils,
For in its  antient  boyls.
whose Waves agen that Fate must know;
whose wild Waters, circling flow.

lines.line_text: If thou the Groaning  Destruction mean,
(Incensed ) Why sleep thy  then?
If thou the cause of this
Or if 'tis some less potent God then
Where's all thy  all thy  care
For Mortals now-that should these Ills repair?
Have I for this thy Sacred  fed
In Hecatombs, to thy high  led?
Those  which with thy bright  smoak,
While  in vain, the gasping-Priests Invoke:
And loe the Mighty  begin to
And, Wher's thy  should they
Tyr'd  of his  complains,
And scarce the  sustains:
But, fainting here, she stop'd, and shrinks her
Below the gloomy  of the Dead.
calls the Gods (with him, whose daring Son,
Too fond of Glory, had this  done:)
To view the  then mounts on high,
The lostyest  that commands the Sky;
From whence he us'd to shade the sultry
And with kind  the Parched  to chear:
But throws his  open now in vain,
And prest the light  for
At which incens'd, his ruddy Thunder glows,
Nor durst the  of  himself oppose.
See the wing'd Vengeance now, see where it breaks,
On the rash cause of those lamented
And sends the bold Usurper breathless down
To the scorch't Earth from his  Throne:
